description: {"blocks":[{"key":"869bc","text":"The Titan_ClearLabs workflow is a part of the Public Health Viral Genomics Titan series for SARS-CoV-2 genomic characterization. Titan_CleanLabs was written to process Clear Labs read data for SARS-CoV-2 ARTIC V3 amplicon sequencing. Upon initiating a Titan_ClearLabs run, input read data provided for each sample will be processed to perform consensus genome assembly, infer the quality of both raw read data and the generated consensus genome, and assign lineage or clade designations as outlined in the Titan_ClearLabs data workflow below.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2kp2t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bc4l","text":"Additional {"blocks":[{"key":"5rmt1","text":"Ideally, at the end of this process, we would have a complete consensus assembly sequence, which represents the entirety of the RNA sequence that was present in the virion in the sample. However, often a full length sequence is not generated at the end of the protocol, but rather fragments of the genome. We can look at metrics to determine how fragmented our genome is relative to the reference sequence. There are 3 metrics in our report to help us assess this. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3hhkh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4kgje","text":"Assembly length unambiguous - the final count of ATCGs (i.e. unambiguous bases) within the consensus assembly. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":27}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ce82","text":"A higher number here will indicate a more complete consensus sequence. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3e5s6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1344s","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"endo5","text":"Here we see that the second sample has only 6,671bp that were unambiguous (A,T,C, or G), which means much of the genome was not able to be recovered through sequencing. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"13m28","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e0mq9","text":"Number of Ns - the converse of assembly length unambiguous - It is the final count of the number of Ns (i.e. ambiguous) bases. These are completely ambiguous bases due to either too little signal or too much noise for the basecaller to confidently determine what base was at this position. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12},{"style":"italic","offset":136,"length":27}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fg0si","text":"If there was an \"S\" (basecaller couldn't tell if it was an C or G) or \"W\" (basecaller couldn't tell if it was an A or T) these counts are considered \"semi-ambiguous\" and are not included in either the number of N or assembly length unambiguous metrics.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"18rsc","text":"A higher number of Ns will mean you have a more fragmented assembly. Less Ns is a strong consensus assembly.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2dkt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"463f0","text":"Percent reference coverage - Portion of the genome covered by consensus assembly. This uses the assembly length unambiguous metric to gauge how much of the reference sequence (Wu Han-1) is covered by the consensus assembly. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":26}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1j6ra","text":"Takes the #ATCG/length of SC2 reference genome (29903bp)*100","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"42e0q","text":"Ideally this should equal 100%, indicating that the assembly covered 100% of the reference genome length, unambiguously.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f9vis","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"blef5","text":"   ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dclea","text":"From these metrics we can see that there is a large number of bases that are Ns (23,232bp), which translates to only 22.31% of the reference genome covered by the sequencing in the second sample. Taken together these metrics indicate that much of the genome sequence is unknown in the second sample, which explains why we were unable to get a pangolin lineage assignment for this sample. The troubleshooting metrics can help determine what caused this. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"85EA5250B20C11EB9F631F1D45720482","height":183,"id":178443,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3ntnt","text":"Assembly length unambiguous metric in the output","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]},"mime":"image/jpeg","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"metric_1.jpg","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/dh6ibi9m7.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/fqimbi9m7.jpg","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/fqikbi9m7.webp","width":550}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"F7E674D0B33B11EB84238D1772444D1F","height":164,"id":178449,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fvthh","text":"Metrics on the number of Ns and percent reference coverage.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]},"mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"tempsnips.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/dig5bi9m7.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/fqitbi9m7.jpg","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/fqisbi9m7.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bg3ld","text":"Pool 1 and 2 Representation (not available in all workflow versions)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":68}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"nf8","text":"We can look at how much read data was generated from each primer pool by looking at the pool 1 and pool 2 percentages. This well help identify if a PCR reaction failed. You want the ratio to be roughly 40:60 in either direction. If there is a 10:90 or 20:80 ratio this is a strong indication that one of the PCR reactions failed and resequencing should be considered to generate a confident consensus sequence for that sample. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"27o4d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dhjns","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"e3pcb","text":"The fact that in the second sample 80% of reads came from pool 1 is an indication that there was a failure to amplify pool 2 in the second sample, which lead to much of the genome not being sequenced in that sample. In contrast, in the first sample there is roughly an even split of the number of reads coming from each primer pool, which is ideal. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8kmu7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7gvia","text":"FastQC Raw Output","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e5t79","text":"These data are the number of raw reads in an input file and indicates how much sequencing occurred.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a811r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ap2rg","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3pghi","text":"These data show that the second sample had significantly fewer reads from the sequencing run. This was another reason the genome that was assembled from the second sample was so fragmented. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"sog","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1n494","text":"Percent of Reads Identified to be Human and SARS-CoV-2","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":54}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d3q3s","text":"These data indicate how much human read contamination is in the sequencing reads. Ideally, the number of reads containing human data should be as low as possible and the percent of reads assigned SARS-CoV-2 should be high. If the sequencing run contains greater than ~15% human reads, the concentration of SARS-CoV-2 in your original sample may be too low to generate sufficient coverage depth for a good quality assembly, or there is an issue in the wet lab protocol that is leading to the low generation of SARS-CoV-2 reads. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":206,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dn31","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ethsg","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bchrh","text":"The first sample is fairly free of contamination, with 99.76% of the sequenced reads belonging to SARS-CoV-2. However, in the second sample there is a high amount of contamination, with 25.37% of reads belonging to human and only 54.19% of reads determined to be of SARS-CoV-2 origin. Thus, there is roughly ~21% of reads that are some other source of contamination that is not human. If a lab is having consistent problem with contamination that is not identified to be of human origin with this workflow, a larger Kraken database can be used to determine the offending organism. Contact TOAST@cdc.gov if you would like assistance with this or read Kraken2's documentation for how to do this on your own. Users should refer to their lab's cut offs for quality metrics to determine if a sample requires resequencing.
